item.title: Ticket #941 (.htaccess generation fails) updated
item.dc:creator: chenu
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #941 (.htaccess generation fails) created
item.dc:creator: chenu
item.description:
My WP 1.5 install does not generate an .htaccess file. My host is running Apache 1.3 on FreeBSD. The Permalink page says that the new settings were saved.

I've had to run my site with a .htaccess file that I generated on my home server. The .htaccess file is chmod'ed to 666.

I saw thread in the support forum about a similar issue and they had changed part of the wp-includes.php as shown below: $is_apache = strstr($_SERVERSERVER_SOFTWARE?, 'Apache') ? 1 : 0; to $is_apache = 1;

I thought that this would help because my host spoofs the server header to say that the server software is Zeus instead of Apache.

item.title: Ticket #940 (CRUFT in get_postdata()) updated
item.dc:creator: skippy
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #940 (CRUFT in get_postdata()) created
item.dc:creator: skippy
item.description:
In functions.php, the get_postdata() function includes the line:

'Category' => $a_post->post_category,

which always returns zero, since the field "Category" in the posts table is no longer used.

See bug #239: â€‹http://mosquito.wordpress.org/view.php?id=239

item.title: Ticket #829 (Editing a post via XML-RPC fails, putting the post into Draft mode) updated
item.dc:creator: michel v
item.description:
This is not a problem with MarsEdit or any particular XMLRPC client.

When the plugin hook for edit_post was added to wp_update_posts, the function was still returning $wpdb->affected_rows directly. The problem is that this value could change, depending on which actions were called by the edit_post hook. In my case for example, a plugin is updating tags, so if nothing changed there, $wpdb->affected_rows becomes 0; so 0 is returned, and xmlrpc.php thinks "whoops, the post wasn't edited".

I'm uploading a simple patch in a second.

item.title: Ticket #924 (RSS2 feed does not validate when using translation mo file) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
mysql2date() accepts an optional third argument that prevents translating the date via the locale tables when set to false. All feeds have been updated to pass a third argument of false to all invocations of mysql2date().

Also, the $use_b2configmonthsdays argument of mysql2date() has been renamed $translate and given a default value of true instead of 1.

item.title: Ticket #935 (client/admin code separation) updated
item.dc:creator: michel v
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #935 (client/admin code separation) created
item.dc:creator: michel v
item.description:
Right now, at every pageview we are loading functions that will never be used in that context: trackback(), do_enclose(), and so on. So we ought to separate those functions and put them in files that would only be required by the admin side of WP.

This bug serves as a tracker to audit the code and find which functions we need and don't need in the following contexts:

  • In the admin
  • On feeds
  • On pages with comments
  • On pages with posts

(list shamelessly copied from Matt's email on hackers@)

item.title: Ticket #901 (apply_filters's handling of extra arguments is broken) updated
item.dc:creator: michel v
item.description:
Uploaded a patch that adds support for both methods, this patch applies on CVS (so after the commit of the previous patch). This patch also fixes do_action so that it too can send extra arguments, and moves the :X parsing to add_filter and remove_filter in order to avoid doing this operation everytime apply_filter is called.

Internally, filters are stored as [tag][priority][array(function, accepted_args)]. It could have been more optimal to store them as [tag][priority][function][accepted_args], since this would allow for simple issets to check for a filter's presence, but this would be incompatible with the usage of class methods (since those are passed as arrays, and we can't use arrays as array keys). To use them as array keys, we could also use serialize/unserialize, but that would add to the operations done when doing apply_filter, so it would be rather bad.

instead of echo $title;

will fix this problem

item.title: Ticket #924 (RSS2 feed does not validate when using translation mo file) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
Try the following patch:

diff -r1.37 wp-rss2.php 36c36 < <pubDate><?php echo mysql2date('D, d M Y H:i:s +0000', get_the_time('Y-m-d H:i:s')); ?></pubDate> ---

<pubDate><?php echo mysql2date('D, d M Y H:i:s +0000', get_the_time('Y-m-d H:i:s'), 0); ?></pubDate>

Everywhere you see a call to mysql2date in a feed file, make sure the call has a third argument of 0.

item.dc:creator: pvera
item.description: Whenever I add/edit or delete a custom field, I am sent to a 404, the URL shows /wp-admin/&message=2#postcustom or /wp-admin/&message=3#postcustom
